CHANGE.ITEM: Added TYPEs to DIVs in order to validate. Proofed title page(s). Check TEXT for LANG attribute. Reviewed structure. Checked division-marking material at heads and feet of divisions (HEADS, CLOSER, OPENER, ARGUMENT, EPIGRAPH, SIGNED, BYLINE, etc.). Checked placement and completeness of PBs. Check for blanks. Checked for signatures. Checked for #s. Checked for Qs, startqs, endqs, oes, q;s. Check LETTER tags. Check Ls. Check TABLEs. Check LISTs. Check NOTEs. Checked for FIGUREs and decorated initials. Checked for missing-page GAPs and duplicates. Checked proofsheets and made corrections found there. Corrected 53 $-groups. Revalidated.

DIV1.P: SONGS AND LULLABIES OF THE GOOD OLD NURSES. CALCULATED to AMUSE CHIL∣DREN. EMBELLISHED WITH CUTS: And illustrated with NOTES and MAXIMS, HISTORICAL, PHILOSOPHICAL and CRITICAL. FIRST WORCESTER EDITION.
Printed at WORCESTER: Massachusetts, BY ISAIAH THOMAS, JUN. Sold Wholesale and Retail by Him—1799.

DIV2.HEAD: A LOVE SONG.

LG.L: And he said, little Maid, will you
I have little more to say,
So will you aye or nay,
For the least said is soonest men∣

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: To induce a little maid for to wed, wed, wed;
You must say a little more,
E'er I make a little print in your Bed, Bed, Bed.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: If you'll be my little bride,
I'll raise my love notes a little high∣er, higher, higher;
Tho' my offers are not meet,
Yet my little heart is great,
With the little God of love all on fire, fire, fire.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: Should I be your little bride,
Pray what must we have for to eat, eat, eat?
Will the flame that you're so rich in
Light a fire in the kitchen,
Or the little God of love turn the spit, spit, spit?

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Then the little man he sigh'd,
And, some say, a little cry'd
For his little heart was big with sorrow, sorrow, sorrow;
As I am your little slave,
If the little that I have
Be too little, little, we will borrow, borrow, borrow.

DIV2.P: He who borrows is another Man's slave, and pawns his honor, his liberty, and sometimes his nose for the .

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: Then the little man so gent,
And set her little heart a think-king, king, king.
Tho' his offers were but small,
She could have but the Cat and her skin, skin, skin.

LG.HEAD: Amphion's SONG of Euridyce.
LG.L: I WONT be my father's Jack,
I wont be my father's Gill
I will be the sidler's wife,
And have music when I will.

DIV2.P: Maxim. Those arts are the most valuable which are of the greatest use.

LG.L: Here a nail, and there a nail,

DIV2.P: Maxim. Knowledge is a treasure, but prac∣tice is the key to it.

LG.L: Jacky shall have a new master:
Jacky must have but a penny a day,
Because he can work no faster.

DIV2.P: mean and scandalous practice in , to things that deferve no
Yes she can see that you are naughty: and don't mind your book.

LG.L: The Cow junno'd over the Moon;
And the dish ran away with the Spoon.

DIV2.P: It must be a little Dog that laugh'd, for a great Dog would be ashamed to laugh at such nonsense.

LG.HEAD: A DIRGE.
LG.L: LITTLE Betty winkle she had a Pig,
It was a little Pig not very big;
When he was alive he liv'd in Clo∣ver,
But now he's dead, and that's all over;
So there was an end of one, two and three,

DIV2.P: A Dirge is a song made for the dead; but whether this was made for Betty Winkle or her Pig is uncertain; no notice being taken of it by Cambden, or any of the famous Anti∣quarians. Wall's System of Sense.

LG.HEAD: A Melancholy SONG.
LG.L: My mother sent me for some bawn, some bawn:
For fear the young men, should do me some harm.
What naughty tricks they put up∣on me,
And kiss'd my sister instead of me.

DIV2.P: What a succession of misfortunes befel this poor girl! But the last circumstance was the most affecting, and might have proved fatal. Winslow's View of Bath.
To be married without a wife is a terrible thing, and to be married with a bad wife is something worse; however, a good wife that sings well is the best musical instrument in the world. Puffendorf.

LG.L: Which is the way to Boston Town?
One foot up the other foot down,
That is the way to Boston Town.

DIV2.P: Or to any other town upon the face of the Earth.
This is a self evident proposition, which is the very essence of truth. She lived under the hill, and if she is not gone she lives there still. Nobody will presume to contradict this. Cusa.

LG.L: She put a mouse in a bag,
By the point of his knife,
Of a mouse in his life.

DIV2.P: The only instance of a Miller refusing toll, and for which the Cat has just cause of com∣plaint against him. Coke upon Littleton.

LG.L: He took him out of the stall,
And put him on the wall,

DIV2.P: Maxim. Those who are given to tell all they know generally tell more than they know

LG.L: Set by the sire and spin;
Take a cup and drink it up,

DIV2.P: A common Case this, to call in our Neigh∣bors to rejoice when all the good Liquor is gone. Pliny.
Ay, ay, drive the nail when it will go: That's the way of the world, and is the meth∣od pursued by all our Financiers, Politicians, and Necromancers. Vattel.

LG.L: And all the Dogs in our town

DIV2.P: Maxim. Point not at the faults of others with a foul anger.

LG.L: WHAT Care I how black I be,
I am my mother's bouncing Girl.

DIV2.P: Maxim. If we do not flatter ourselves, the flattery of others would have no effect

LG.HEAD: PLATO's SONG.
LG.L: The cat is in the well.
What a naughty boy was that
And kill'd the mice in his father's barn.

DIV2.P: Maxim. He that injures one threatens an Hundred.

LG.L: To see what Tommy can buy;
And a two penny Apple Pye.

DIV2.P: There's a good boy, eat up your pye and hold your tongue; for silence is the sign of wisdom.

LG.L: They went to sea in a bowl,
And if the bowl had been stronger,

DIV2.P: It is long enough. Never lament the loss of what is not worth having. Boyle.
